contextId.occurrenceNote: To “pollute” something is to make is unclean. Some of the food and drink of the Babylonians would make Daniel ceremonially unclean according to God’s law. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “make himself unclean according to God’s law” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: pollute himself

contextId.occurrenceNote: Daniel probably went to the palace. Alternate translation: “Daniel went to the palace” or “Daniel went to talk with the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Daniel went in

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to God. Alternate translation: “God, who reveals mysteries” or “God, who makes mysteries known” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the one who reveals mysteries

contextId.occurrenceNote: In the king’s dream his kingdom is gold so an inferior kingdom would be silver. Alternate translation: “another kingdom, which is of silver, will arise” or “another kingdom, which is represented by the silver parts of the statue, will arise” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: another kingdom will arise

contextId.occurrenceNote: It can be made clear that the holy messenger was speaking to more than one person. Alternate translation: “He shouted to some people and said” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: He shouted and said

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase probably refers to angels. Alternate translation: “the holy angels” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the holy ones

contextId.occurrenceNote: Daniel’s understanding of the meaning of the vision is what alarmed him. This can be explicitly stated. Alternate translation: “did not say anything for some time because he was very worried about the meaning of the dream” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: was greatly upset for a while, and his thoughts alarmed him

contextId.occurrenceNote: It may be helpful to add additional detail. Alternate translation: “When he decides to do something, no one can stop him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: No one can stop him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Purple cloth was rare and reserved for royal officials. Alternate translation: “dressed in royal clothing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: clothed with purple

contextId.occurrenceNote: Purple cloth was rare and reserved for royal officials. Alternate translation: “dressed in royal clothing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: clothed with purple

contextId.occurrenceNote: What and where “his house” is can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: “From his temple in Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: From his house

contextId.occurrenceNote: The other administrators were jealous of Daniel. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “Then the other chief administrators and the provincial governors became jealous. So they looked for mistakes in the work Daniel did for the kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Then the other chief administrators and the provincial governors & for the kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: The men were implying that since no decree or statute of the king can be changed, Daniel must be thrown into the pit of lions. This can be stated clearly if needed. Alternate translation: “no decree … can be changed. They must throw Daniel into the pit of lions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: no decree & can be changed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The function of the signet ring can be stated clearly. The king and the noblemen pressed their rings into a seal made of wax. Alternate translation: “the king pressed his signet ring into a wax seal, the nobles did this too. No one was allowed to break the seal and help Daniel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the king sealed it with his own signet ring and with the signet rings of his nobles & concerning Daniel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The animal was killed because the judge determined that it was guilty. Alternate translation: “they executed the animal” or “the judge commanded and they killed the animal” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the animal was killed

contextId.occurrenceNote: They will rule one after the other. This can be stated explicitly. Alternate translation: “ten kings will rule over this fourth kingdom, one after another” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: out of this kingdom ten kings will arise

contextId.occurrenceNote: This other king is not one of the ten. It may be helpful to refer to him as “the eleventh king.” Alternate translation: “after that an eleventh king will become powerful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: another will arise after them

contextId.occurrenceNote: He will defeat three of the original ten kings. It may be helpful to state that those three kings are represented by the three horns that were pulled out. Alternate translation: “he will defeat the three kings that were represented by the three horns that were pulled out” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: he will conquer the three kings

contextId.occurrenceNote: Goats have two horns on the sides of their heads. This image should be explained. Alternate translation: “The goat had a single large horn in the center of his head” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: The goat had a large horn between his eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to God himself, who is the leader of the angel army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the commander of the army

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the time when God will judge. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “the time when God judges in anger” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the time of wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: The four horns represent the four new kingdoms. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “they represent the four kingdoms into which the kingdom of the first king will be divided” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: four kingdoms will arise from his nation

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that the angel will tell Daniel about this immediately, before he goes away. Alternate translation: “But first I will tell you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: But I will tell you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Darius was the King of the Medes. “The first year” refers to the first year that he was king. Alternate translation: “In the first year of the reign of Darius” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: In the first year of Darius

contextId.occurrenceNote: The tax collector will go through the land forcing people to pay taxes. Alternate translation: “will send someone to make the people pay taxes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: will make a tax collector pass through

contextId.occurrenceNote: This implies that the king will do certain actions in Israel. Alternate translation: “He will do what he wants to in Israel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: He will act

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nothing will stop the army. Alternate translation: “will pass through the lands with no one to stop him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: pass through

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the idea is many lands or various lands. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: into lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This seems to happen before “the time of the end” during which time the book is sealed. This can be made explicit. Alternate translation: “Before that happens, many people will travel here and there, learning more and more about many things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: Many will run here and there, and knowledge will increase

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king of the north is the one who stops the temple sacrifices. Alternate translation: “the king of the North takes away the regular burnt offering and sets up the abomination that causes complete desolation” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: the regular burnt offering is & is set up

contextId.occurrenceNote: A cubit is 46 centimeters. Alternate translation: “about 27 meters tall and almost 3 meters wide” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-bdistance]])
contextId.quoteString: sixty cubits tall and six cubits wide

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the first month of the Hebrew calendar. The twenty-fourth day is near the middle of April on Western calendars. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-hebrewmonths]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: On the twenty-fourth day of the first month

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the chief official. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Ashpenaz

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are all men’s names. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Belteshazzar & Shadrach & Meshach & Abednego

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the language that people in Babylon spoke. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Aramaic

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the name of the king’s commander. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Arioch

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a location within the kingdom of Babylon. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Plain of Dura

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the son of Nebuchadnezzar who became king after his father. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Belshazzar

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are names of places. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Susa & Elam & Ulai Canal

contextId.occurrenceNote: Uphaz is a place. Its location is not known (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Uphaz

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may refer to a settlement on the island of Cyprus in the Mediterranean Sea. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: Kittim

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the people of Libya and Cush.” Libya is a country west of Egypt, and Cush is a country south of Egypt. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])
contextId.quoteString: the Libyans and the Cushites

contextId.occurrenceNote: This symbolic act showed that the king was honoring Daniel. Alternate translation: “lay down with his face on the ground” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: fell on his face

contextId.occurrenceNote: “stretch yourselves out on the ground face down in worship of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: prostrate yourselves to

contextId.occurrenceNote: They did this to worship the statue. Alternate translation: “stretched themselves out on the ground face down in worship of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: prostrated themselves to

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people would do this to worship the statue. Alternate translation: “stretch himself out on the ground face down in worship of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: prostrate himself to

contextId.occurrenceNote: They would do this to worship the statue. Alternate translation: “stretch themselves out on the ground face down in worship” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: prostrate themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: The three men would not do this to worship the statue. Alternate translation: “stretch yourselves out on the ground face down in worship of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: prostrate yourselves to

contextId.occurrenceNote: stretch yourselves out on the ground face down in worship of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: prostrate yourselves to

contextId.occurrenceNote: People would do this to worship their gods. Alternate translation: “stretch ourselves out on the ground face down in worship of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: prostrate ourselves to

contextId.occurrenceNote: People would do this to worship their gods. Alternate translation: “stretch themselves out on the ground face down in honor of” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: prostrate themselves to

contextId.occurrenceNote: This symbolic act showed that the king was worried about Daniel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: he went through the night fasting

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an act of worship in which someone lies flat on the ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: prostrated myself on the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are symbolic acts of repentance and sorrow. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: fasting, wearing sackcloth, and sitting in ashes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Anointing is a symbolic act to show that someone is chosen. Alternate translation: “the person that God anoints” or “the person that God chooses” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.quoteString: the anointed one

contextId.occurrenceNote: In the king’s dream the statue’s head represents the king. Alternate translation: “The golden head symbolizes you” or “The golden head is a symbol of you and your power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: You are the statue’s head of gold

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is symbolic language where the bronze of parts of the statue represent a future kingdom. Alternate translation: “then still another kingdom, which is represented by the bronze parts of the statue” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: yet a third kingdom of bronze

contextId.occurrenceNote: This symbolic language means the fourth kingdom will defeat and replace the other kingdoms. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: It will shatter all these things and crush them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is symbolic language that exaggerates how tall and how well-known the tree was. Alternate translation: “It seemed that its top reached up to the sky and that everyone in the world could see it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: Its top reached to the heavens & it could be seen to the ends of the whole earth

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Chapters 7 and 8 are not in chronological order. They happened while Belshazzar was still the king, before the rule of Darius and Cyrus that was discussed in chapter 6. In Daniel’s vision, he saw animals that were symbols of other things. Later in the vision someone explains the meaning of those symbols. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was a symbolic creature, and not an animal that exists. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: The first was like a lion but had eagle’s wings

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was not an actual bear, but a symbolic animal that was similar to a bear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: a second animal, like a bear

contextId.occurrenceNote: This was not an actual leopard, but a symbolic animal that was similar to a leopard. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: another animal, one that looked like a leopard

contextId.occurrenceNote: The four wings and four heads are symbols, but their meaning is unclear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: four wings & four heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is also not an actual animal. It is a symbolic creature. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: a fourth animal & it had ten horns

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Most of the text of verses 9-14 is symbolic language with parallel lines that have similar meaning. For this reason, the ULT and UST present them in poetic form. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Most of the text of verses 9-14 is symbolic language with parallel lines that have similar meaning. For this reason, the ULT presents them in poetic form. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Most of the text of verses 23-27 is symbolic language. For this reason, the ULT presents them in poetic form. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

Chapters 7 and 8 are not in chronological order. They happened while Belshazzar was still the king, before the rule of Darius and Cyrus that was discussed in chapter 6. In Daniel’s vision, he saw animals that were symbols of other things. Later in the vision someone explains the meaning of those symbols. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: It is normal for rams to have two horns. These horns, however, have symbolic meaning. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: a ram with two horns

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In these verses, the angel explains to Daniel the symbolic meaning of the things he saw in his vision. The animals and horns actually represent human rulers and kingdoms. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In these verses, the angel explains to Daniel the symbolic meaning of the things he saw in his vision. The animals and horns actually represented human rulers or kingdoms. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In these verses, the angel explains to Daniel the symbolic meaning of the things he saw in his vision. The animals and horns actually represented human rulers or kingdoms. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-symlanguage]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: “No one can question what he does.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
contextId.quoteString: No one can say to him, ‘Why have you done this?’

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is background information that explains how Daniel’s enemies knew he was praying to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: now his windows were open in his upper room toward Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is background information to remind the reader that this is Daniel’s second vision. Alternate translation: “had a second vision appear to me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: had a vision appear to me (after the one & first)

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is background information about who Ahasuerus was. The UST places this in parentheses to make that clear. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])
contextId.quoteString: It was Ahasuerus who had been made king over the realm of the Babylonians

index.name: Introduction of New and Old Participants

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean approximately the same thing and emphasize that these are “lies intended to deceive.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: false and deceptive words

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the greatness of the king’s power. Alternate translation: “most powerful” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: great and powerful

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of his anger. Alternate translation: “incredibly angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: angry and very furious

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the greatness of his prudence. Alternate translation: “caution and careful judgment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: prudence and discretion

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words mean basically the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: the power, the strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words share similar meanings and refer to the amazing things that God had done. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: signs and wonders

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: my house & my palace

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean basically the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: a dream & the images & the visions

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the greatness of his glory. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: majesty and splendor

contextId.occurrenceNote: All three of these words have basically the same meaning and emphasize how greatly he praised God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: praise, extol, and honor

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of the fear. Alternate translation: “were very afraid of him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: trembled and feared him

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words are similar and can be combined. Alternate translation: “shake with fear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: tremble and fear

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “dream” and “visions” both refer to the same dream that is described in this chapter. Alternate translation: “visions while he was dreaming” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: a dream and visions

contextId.occurrenceNote: This repetition of ideas emphasizes that this kingdom will never come to an end. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: forever and ever

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two terms mean basically the same thing and emphasize that this will concern all forms of official authority. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: The kingdom and the dominion

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “commands” and “decrees” share similar meanings and refer to the whole law. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: your commands and decrees

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “anger” and “wrath” mean basically the same thing and emphasize how terrible God’s anger is when he acts on it. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: your anger and your wrath

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “insight” and “understanding” mean the same thing and emphasize that Gabriel will help Daniel to understand the message completely. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: insight and understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words in this context mean the same thing. They ensure Daniel that Jeremiah’s vision was indeed a prophecy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: the vision and the prophecy

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are used together to make the importance clear. Alternate translation: “You must clearly understand” or “You must know for sure” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Know and understand

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words basically mean the same thing. The repetition is to show that the ruler will prevent all types of sacrifices. Alternate translation: “all forms of sacrificing” or “every type of offering” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: the sacrifice and the offering

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two words or expressions are basically the same. They emphasize how serious and complete the destruction will be. Alternate translation: “Complete destruction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: A full end and destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases “lift himself up” and “make himself great” mean the same thing and indicate that the king will become very proud. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: lift himself up and make himself great

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idea of not being divided and shared out is implied here. Alternate translation: “but it will not be divided for his own descendants” or “but it will not be shared by his own descendants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.quoteString: but not to his own descendants

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “fell down” is a euphemism that means they were destroyed.” Alternate translation: “which destroyed the three horns” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: before which the three horns fell down

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “sleep in the dust of the earth” is another way of referring to those who have died. Here “rise up” is an idiom that means to come back to life. Alternate translation: “those who have died will come back to life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: those who sleep in the dust of the earth will rise up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a gentle way of saying “you will die.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.quoteString: you will rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “all” is a generalization to show that they had a very good education and understanding. Alternate translation: “in many things that the Babylonians had written and studied” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: in all literature and wisdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “ten times” is an exaggeration representing great quality. Alternate translation: “much better” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: ten times better

contextId.occurrenceNote: Kings would often exaggerate how wide their kingdom was. Nebuchadnezzar did rule over most of the known world at the time this book was written. Alternate translation: “who lived in the kingdom of Babylon” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: who lived on the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases are exaggerations to emphasize that everyone everywhere knew how great Nebuchadnezzar was. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: to the heavens & to the ends of the whole earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase uses the word “all” as a generalization that represents a large number. Alternate translation: “a great number of people, of different nations and languages” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: all peoples, nations, and languages

contextId.occurrenceNote: King Darius wrote his message to his entire kingdom which was huge. Here it says “all the earth” as a generalization to emphasis how large his kingdom was, though it did not include everyone on the earth. Alternate translation: “in his kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: in all the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase “the whole earth” is an exaggeration that means he came from far away. Alternate translation: “from far away across the surface of the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.quoteString: across the surface of the whole earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. This means they knew much and could organize and use that information. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: filled with knowledge and understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “The king might cut off my head” or “The king might kill me” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: The king might have my head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “seven times hotter” is an idiom that means to make it very much hotter. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “He commanded his men to make the furnace very much hotter than they normally make it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: He commanded that the furnace should be heated seven times hotter than it was normally heated

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase refers to the three men’s willingness to die for what they believed. Alternate translation: “they were willing to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: they gave up their bodies

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means the king was still in the act of speaking. Alternate translation: “While the king was still speaking” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: While the words were still on the lips of the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase uses “walk” to refer to the person who acts proud. Alternate translation: “who are proud” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: who walk in their own pride

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means he ignores the king. Alternate translation: “does not obey you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: pays no attention to you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom that means he sat down. Alternate translation: “sat down on his throne” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: took his seat

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “from the earth” means they are real people. Alternate translation: “four kings who will come to power on the earth” or “four men who will rise up from among the people of the earth and become kings” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: four kings that will arise from the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the newest king will openly disagree with and say bad things about the Most High. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: He will speak words against the Most High

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idiom “under the whole heaven” refers to the kingdoms on earth. Alternate translation: “of all the kingdoms on earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: of the kingdoms under the whole heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “the four winds of heaven” is an idiom that refers to the four main directions (north, east, south, west) from which the winds blow. Alternate translation: “in four different directions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: toward the four winds of the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a reference to the land of Israel. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the land of beauty

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom means their shame is visible to all. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: belongs shame on our faces

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words “turned aside” mean that Israel stopped obeying God’s laws. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: turned aside

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom. Alternate translation: “For in the whole world” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: For under the whole of heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here stopping evil activity is spoken of as turning away from them. Alternate translation: “stopping our evil actions” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: turning away from our iniquities

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “open the ears” is an idiom that means to listen. These two phrases means the same thing and emphasize Daniel’s desire for God to listen to his prayer. Alternate translation: “please listen” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: open your ears and listen

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “open the eyes” is an idiom that means to see. These two phrases means the same thing and emphasize Daniel’s desire for God to pay attention to his prayer. Alternate translation: “notice us” or “pay attention” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: open your eyes and see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “carry out” is an idiom that means to accomplish. Alternate translation: “to accomplish the vision” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: to carry out the vision

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes the face of someone who is healthy. Alternate translation: “my healthy-looking face” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: my bright appearance

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are: (1) Daniel was so scared by what he saw that he deliberately laid on the ground, where he then fainted or (2) Daniel fainted and then fell forward onto the ground. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: I fell on my face in deep sleep

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this expression refers to human beings in general. Alternate translation: “like a human being” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: like the sons of man

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idiom refers to breathing. Alternate translation: “I cannot breathe” or “it’s very hard to breathe” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: there is no breath left in me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an idiom for a person deciding to do something and not being willing to change his mind. Alternate translation: “decide” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: set his face

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an elegant way of saying “a woman.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: a daughter of women

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a way of saying that he will die. This idea can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “he will disappear” or “he will die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: he will not be found

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “fall” is an idiom that refers to dying in battle, so “fall” and “killed” mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “many of his soldiers will die in battle” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: many of them will fall killed

contextId.occurrenceNote: “His army will appear” or “His army will come.” The word “His” refers to the king of the North. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: His forces will rise up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to an idol that will make the temple desolate, that is, that will cause God to leave his temple. Alternate translation: “the disgusting idol that will cause God to abandon the temple” or “the disgusting thing that will make the temple unclean” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the abomination that causes desolation

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the one true God. Alternate translation: “the supreme God” or “the only true God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the God of gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “footsteps” represent submission. Alternate translation: “the Libyans and the Cushites will have to serve him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: the Libyans and the Cushites will be in his footsteps

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “rise up” is an idiom that means to appear. Alternate translation: “Michael … will appear” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Michael & will rise up

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two negative words together emphasize a positive idea. Alternate translation: “with perfect appearance” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.quoteString: without blemish

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah pleased him much more than anyone else in the whole group” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.quoteString: among the whole group there were none to compare with Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is stated in negative form for emphasis. It can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “only the gods can tell this to the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.quoteString: there is no one who can tell it to the king except the gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “they were completely gone” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.quoteString: there was no trace of them left

contextId.occurrenceNote: A decision that will not be changed is spoken of as something firm. Alternate translation: “you see that I will not change my decision about this” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: you see how firm my decision is about this

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nebuchadnezzar’s anger and rage were so intense that they are spoken of as if they had filled him up. Here “anger” and “rage” mean about the same thing and are used to emphasize how upset the king was. Alternate translation: “extremely angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: filled with anger and rage

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king was so angry that rage is spoken of as if it were filling him up. Alternate translation: “Nebuchadnezzar became extremely angry” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuchadnezzar was filled with rage

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not obeying the king’s command is spoken of as if they had physically moved it away from them. Alternate translation: “they ignored my command” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they set aside my command

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here rejecting iniquity is spoken of as turning away from it. Alternate translation: “Reject your iniquities” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Turn away from your iniquities

contextId.occurrenceNote: To rebel against God is spoken of as raising oneself up against him. Alternate translation: “You have rebelled against the Lord” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: You have lifted yourself up against the Lord

contextId.occurrenceNote: Judging the worthiness of the king to rule is spoken of as weighing him. This means that the king is not worthy to rule. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God has examined your worthiness to rule, and he has found that you are not worthy” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: you are weighed in the scales and are found lacking

contextId.occurrenceNote: The quick way in which fire came from the presence of God is spoken of as if it was water flowing in a river. Alternate translation: “Fire poured out in front of him like water in a river” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: A river of fire flowed out from before him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This does not mean the fourth kingdom will destroy the planet, but that it will brutally attack, conquer, and destroy all other kingdoms on earth. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: It will devour & it into pieces

contextId.occurrenceNote: The horn ignoring truth and godliness is spoken of as if it will throw truth to the ground. Alternate translation: “The horn will reject the truth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: The horn will throw truth down to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: The angel speaks about the vision as if it were a scroll that could be closed with a wax seal. This prevented anyone from seeing the contents until the seal was broken. Alternate translation: “close and seal up what you have written about the vision” or “do not tell anyone about the vision now” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: seal up the vision

contextId.occurrenceNote: Those who want to know Yahweh and please him are spoken of as if they are literally seeking to find Yahweh. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: to seek him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being righteous is spoken of as if “righteousness” were an object that belongs to Yahweh. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **righteousness**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “righteous.” Alternate translation: “Lord, you are righteous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: To you, Lord, belongs righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being ashamed is spoken of as if “shame” were an object that belongs to people. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **shame**, you can express the same idea with a verbal form such as “ashamed.” Alternate translation: “But as for us, we are ashamed of what we have done—the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.quoteString: To us today, however, belongs shame on our faces—for the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Having these traits is spoken of as if they belonged to the Lord. Alternate translation: “The Lord our God is compassionate and forgives” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: To the Lord our God belong compassion and forgiveness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The abundance of the curse and the oath are spoken of as if they were poured out like water. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “you have brought upon us” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: have been poured out on us

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably as if Yahweh’s face shone a light. Alternate translation: “act kindly toward” or “act with favor toward” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: make your face shine on

contextId.occurrenceNote: The army will destroy the city and the holy place just as a flood destroys things. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Its end will come with a flood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Someone’s unhealthy, pale face is spoken of as if it were a ruined building. Alternate translation: “pale” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a ruined look

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idea of rising up or standing is often used for someone who becomes powerful. Alternate translation: “A mighty king will begin to reign” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: A mighty king will rise up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “arm” stands for power. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: her arm’s strength & his arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: This family is spoken of as if it were a tree. The roots represent ancestors, and the branch represents a descendant. Alternate translation: “a descendant of her ancestors” or “one of her descendants” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: a branch from her roots

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being lifted up represents the idea of becoming very proud. Alternate translation: “will become very proud” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will be lifted up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the idea of rising up represents rebelling. Alternate translation: “many people will rebel against the king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: many will rise against the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression stands for violent people. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Sons of the violent

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here stumbling represents failing. Alternate translation: “they will not succeed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: they will stumble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “destruction” represents the power to destroy. Also, the power to destroy is spoken of as if it were something that someone could hold in his hand. Alternate translation: “he will have power to destroy anything” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: destruction will be in his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rising up in a king’s place represents becoming king in place of the previous king. Alternate translation: “another man will become king of the North instead of that king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: someone will rise up in his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “he” refers to the new king. Being broken represents dying. Alternate translation: “the new king will die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will be broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) no one was angry at the king, or (2) that the occasion and cause of the king’s death were kept secret. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: but not in anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this represents courage. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not standing represents being defeated. Alternate translation: “the king of the South will be defeated” or “his army will be defeated” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: he will not stand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the severe defeat of an army is spoken of as a flood of water that completely sweeps it away. Alternate translation: “The enemy will completely defeat his army” or “His enemy will completely destroy his army as a flood destroys everything in its path” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: His army will be swept away like a flood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents a person’s desires. Desires are spoken of here as if they were an object that someone could set or place in a certain position. Alternate translation: “each determined to do evil to the other” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: with their hearts set on evil against each other

contextId.occurrenceNote: Taking away the offering represents preventing people from offering it. Alternate translation: “They will stop the priests from presenting the regular burnt offering” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: They will take away the regular burnt offering

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “stumble” is a metaphor that represents experiencing a disaster of one kind or another, including death itself. Here “sword” represents battles and warfare, and “flame” represents fire. Alternate translation: “they will die in battle and by burning to death” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: they will stumble by the sword and by flame

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “stumble” is a metaphor that represents experiencing a disaster of one kind or another, including death itself. The phrase “being robbed” can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “they will become slaves and their enemies will rob them of their possessions for days” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they will stumble into captivity and into being robbed for days

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “join themselves” represents “come to help.” Alternate translation: “will come to help them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will join themselves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “stumble” represents experiencing a disaster of one kind or another, including death itself. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: Some of the wise will stumble

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the purifying of metal by melting it in a fire. When God makes his people more faithful to himself, this is spoken of as if they were metal that a worker was making more pure by putting it into fire. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: refining

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to making people, places, or objects suitable for God’s use by separating them from sin and other forms of evil. It speaks of evil as if it were physical dirtiness that could be removed by washing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: cleansing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This idea is very similar to refining, discussed earlier. Metal that is refined can also be said to be purified. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: purifying

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this represents becoming very proud. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: lift himself up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this represents pretending to be very important and powerful. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: make himself great

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase pictures God as storing up his wrath until his storeroom is completely full of it and he is ready to act according to it. Alternate translation: “until God is completely angry with him” or “until God is angry enough to take action against him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: until the wrath is completed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Violently attacking with an army is spoken of as if a storm happened. Alternate translation: “will attack him like a violent storm” or “will violently attack him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: will storm against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power and control. Alternate translation: “He will extend his control over various lands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: He will extend his hand into lands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to those who help others understand that they are separated from God, as if they were changing the direction in which they were going. Alternate translation: “those who teach others to live righteously” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: those who turn many to righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The vision that was given to Daniel was not to be explained. The book was sealed and no one could access it. Alternate translation: “for you are to close up and seal the words you have written” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: for the words are shut up and sealed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king’s officials did this task for him. Alternate translation: “The king’s officials counted out for them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: The king counted out for them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mind” refers to his thoughts. Alternate translation: “His thoughts disturbed him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: His mind was troubled

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” refers to God himself. Alternate translation: “Praise God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Praise the name of God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being on the “throne” refers to ruling over a kingdom. Alternate translation: “makes new kings rule over their kingdoms” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: places kings on their thrones

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to control. Alternate translation: “He has given you control over the place” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He has given into your hand the place

contextId.occurrenceNote: The place is used to represent the people who live there. Alternate translation: “the people of the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the place where the human beings live

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to control. Alternate translation: “He has given you control over the animals of the fields and the birds of the heavens” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He has given over the animals & into your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nebuchadnezzar commanded his men to do this work, he did not do the work himself. Alternate translation: “Nebuchadnezzar commanded his men to make a gold statue … They set it up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuchadnezzar made a gold statue & He set it up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nebuchadnezzar commanded his men to do this work, he did not do the work himself. Alternate translation: “the statue that Nebuchadnezzar’s men had set up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the statue that Nebuchadnezzar had set up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “nations” and “languages” represent people from different nations who speak different languages. Alternate translation: “people from different nations and who speak different languages” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: peoples, nations, and languages

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nebuchadnezzar commanded his men to do this work, he did not do the work himself. Alternate translation: “the golden statue that King Nebuchadnezzar’s men had set up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the golden statue that Nebuchadnezzar the king had set up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nebuchadnezzar commanded his men to do this work, he did not do the work himself. Alternate translation: “the golden statue your men have set up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the golden statue you have set up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mind” refers to deciding. To “make up your mind” is an idiom that means to firmly decide. Alternate translation: “Have you firmly decided” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: Have you made your minds up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nebuchadnezzar commanded his men to do this work, he did not do the work himself. Alternate translation: “the golden statue that my men have set up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the golden statue that I have set up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nebuchadnezzar commanded his men to do this work, he did not do the work himself. Alternate translation: “the statue that my men have made” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the statue that I have made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hands” refers to power to punish. Alternate translation: “from my punishment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: out of my hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to power to punish. Alternate translation: “from your punishment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: out of your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nebuchadnezzar commanded his men to do this work, he did not do the work himself. Alternate translation: “the golden statue your men set up” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the golden statue you set up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is referring to the king’s messenger as the king himself. Alternate translation: “Nebuchadnezzar sent his messengers with” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: King Nebuchadnezzar sent

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heaven” refers to God who lives in heaven. Alternate translation: “God in heaven is the ruler of all” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: heaven rules

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “throne” refers to his authority to rule. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “I returned to rule my kingdom again, and I received even more greatness” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: I was brought & greatness was given to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “Nebuchadnezzar” refers to Nebuchadnezzar’s army. Alternate translation: “his father Nebuchadnezzar’s army” or “the army of Nebuchadnezzar his father had taken” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuchadnezzar his father had taken

contextId.occurrenceNote: In this phrase “father” is being used to represent all of the soldiers. Alternate translation: “whom my father’s soldiers brought out of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: whom my father the king brought out of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase does not mean King Nebuchadnezzar put people to death himself, but rather those he commanded. Alternate translation: “Nebuchadnezzar commanded his soldiers to kill those he wanted to die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He put to death those he wanted to die

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “throne” refers to his authority to rule. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the people took away his kingdom” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: he was brought down from his kingly throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mind” represents his thoughts. Alternate translation: “he thought as an animal thinks” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he had the mind of an animal

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “breath” refers to life and “hand” refers to power or control. Alternate translation: “God who gives you breath” or “God who has control over your entire life” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: God who holds your breath in his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mind” refers to his thinking. Alternate translation: “he thought very hard about how” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he applied his mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mind” refers to thinking. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “Someone gave it the ability to think like a human being” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The mind of a man was given to it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Translators may write a footnote like this: “Horns are a symbol of power and represent powerful leaders.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the horns

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “his hand” refers to his control. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “The newest king will control the religous festivals and laws” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: These things will be given into his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rams do not have hands. Here “hand” refers to the ram’s power. Alternate translation: “to rescue anyone from him” or “to rescue anyone from his power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: to rescue anyone out of his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this refers to the kings of Media and Persia or (2) this is a metonym in which the kings represents the kingdoms of Media and Persia. Alternate translation: “the kingdoms of Media and Persia” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the kings of Media and Persia

contextId.occurrenceNote: This could mean: (1) this refers to the king of Greece or (2) this is a metonym in which the king represents the kingdom of Greece. Alternate translation: “the kingdom of Greece” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the king of Greece

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to his rule. Alternate translation: “under his rule” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: under his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “he” refers to his power. Alternate translation: “his rule will end” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: he will be broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” refers to power. This can be also stated in positive form. Alternate translation: “not by any human power” or “by divine power” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: not by any human hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “face” represents Daniel’s attention. Alternate translation: “I focused my attention on the Lord God” or “I directed my thoughts toward the Lord God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: I turned my face to the Lord God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “not listened” means they did not obey their message. Alternate translation: “We have not obeyed the message of your prophets” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: We have not listened to your servants

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” refers to God’s authority. Alternate translation: “spoke with your authority” or “spoke as your representative” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: spoke in your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “voice” refers to the commands that Yahweh spoke. Alternate translation: “We have not obeyed what Yahweh told us to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: We have not obeyed the voice of Yahweh our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “voice” refers to the things that Yahweh commanded. Alternate translation: “we have not done what he told us to do” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: we have not obeyed his voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mighty hand” is a metonym for strength. Alternate translation: “with great strength” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: with a mighty hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “name” represents ownership. Alternate translation: “is your city” or “belongs to you” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: is called by your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may refer to the defensive structures on top of the walls of the temple, which are called “abominations” because they are full of idols. Alternate translation: “the walls of the temple that are full of abominations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: the wing of abominations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here falling represents dying in battle. Alternate translation: “will have his army kill many thousands of his enemies” or “will kill many thousands of his enemies” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will make tens of thousands to fall

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here standing represents the ability to fight. Alternate translation: “will not be able to keep fighting against them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will not be able to stand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here standing represents ruling. Alternate translation: “The king will begin to rule” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: He will stand in

contextId.occurrenceNote: This probably refers to military power. Alternate translation: “come with the force of all his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: come with the strength of his entire kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the king’s advisers. It was usual for a king’s most trusted advisers to eat meals with him. Alternate translation: “the king’s best advisers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: those who eat his fine food

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sitting at the same table represents the act of talking to each other. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will sit at the same table

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” represents the mind or thoughts of a person. The idiom “his heart set against” means to be determined to oppose something. This can be stated as a new sentence. Alternate translation: “riches. He will be determined to oppose the holy covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: riches, with his heart set against the holy covenant

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king’s desire to act against the holy covenant represents his desire to stop the Israelites from obeying that covenant. Alternate translation: “determined to stop the Israelites from obeying the holy covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: with his heart set against the holy covenant

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ships represent the army coming in those ships. Alternate translation: “an army will come from Kittim in ships in order to fight his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: ships of Kittim will come against him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “know” means “be faithful.” Alternate translation: “who are faithful to their God” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: who know their God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here falling represents the action of dying. Alternate translation: “will die” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: will fall

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents power. Alternate translation: “But these will escape from his power” or “But he will not be able to destroy these nations” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: But these will escape from his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: To “go out” represents the action of attacking the enemy. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: go out

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “words” represents the book. Alternate translation: “close this book and keep it sealed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.quoteString: close up these words; keep the book sealed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases have the same meaning and are used to emphasize how great God’s signs and wonders are. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: How great are his signs, and how mighty are his wonders!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases have the same meaning and are repeated to emphasize how God’s reign is forever. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: His kingdom is & generation to generation

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel and mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: was living happily & was enjoying prosperity

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases are parallel and they mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: made me afraid & troubled me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean similar things. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: Your greatness has grown & your authority reaches

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two phrases refer to the same action. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: I praised & and I honored

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are used to emphasize how God’s reign never ends. Alternate translation: “He rules forever and his kingdom will never end” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: For his reign is an everlasting reign & his kingdom endures from all generations to all generations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two phrases “the living God” and “lives forever” express the same concept, that God lives forever. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: he is the living God and lives forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are parallel, emphasizing how God’s kingdom will never end. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: his kingdom shall & his dominion shall

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: will not pass away & will never be destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases describe how Daniel was feeling. The second one gives more information about the first one, explaining about his grieved spirit. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: my spirit was grieved inside of me & the visions I saw in my mind troubled me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases express one idea in two different ways for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: We have sinned and have done what is wrong

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases express one idea in two different ways for emphasis. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: We have acted wickedly and we have rebelled

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses mean basically the same thing and are used together to emphasize how bad sin is. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: still we sinned; we have done wicked things

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idea is repeated to emphasize how certain it is that this will happen. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.quoteString: to end the guilt and put an end to sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: The decree is spoken of as if it was alive and able to go out by itself. Alternate translation: “So the king issued a command” or “So the king gave a command” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: So the decree went out

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is using the word “grown” as a way of saying the king’s greatness has increased. Alternate translation: “Your greatness has increased” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: Your greatness has grown

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here his sanity is spoken of as if it was able to return by its own power. Alternate translation: “I became sane again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: my sanity returned to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here his majesty and splendor are spoken of as if they were able to return by their own power. Alternate translation: “I regained my majesty and my splendor again” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: my majesty and splendor returned to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sleep is spoken of as if it could run away from the king. Alternate translation: “he did not sleep at all that night” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: sleep fled from him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the horn is given qualities of a person and is engaging in war. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: It became so large as to engage in war

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the horn is given qualities of a person that tramples on the stars and on the army. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: it trampled on them

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

The horn is given qualities of a person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “deceit” is spoken of as if it is a person who will prosper. Alternate translation: “the amount of deception will increase” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: he will make deceit prosper

contextId.occurrenceNote: Power and heart (that is, courage) are spoken of as if they were people whom someone could wake up in order to make them act. Alternate translation: “He will make himself powerful and will become courageous” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.quoteString: He will wake up his power and his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: The official uses this question to explain what he thought would happen. It can be a statement. Alternate translation: “He does not want to see you looking worse than the other young men of your own age.” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Why should he see you looking worse than the other young men of your own age?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king does not expect an answer. He is threatening the three men. Alternate translation: “No god is able to rescue you from my power!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Who is the god & my hands?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Nebuchadnezzar asks this question to emphasize his own glory. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this question as a statement. Alternate translation: “This is the great Babylon … for the glory of my majesty!” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: Is this not the great Babylon & for the glory of my majesty?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Daniel asks this question meaning that he cannot speak to the angel because he is not the angel’s equal. These sentences can be combined. Alternate translation: “I am not able to answer you because I am only your servant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.quoteString: I am your servant & ow can I talk with my master?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is comparing the pieces of the statue to small and light things which could be blown away by the wind. Alternate translation: “like dry pieces of grass blowing away in the wind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: like the chaff of the threshing floors in the summer

contextId.occurrenceNote: The fourth kingdom is spoken of as being as strong as iron. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: strong as iron

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something about God’s hair looked like pure wool. This could mean: (1) it was very white or (2) it was thick and curly. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: the hair of his head was like pure wool

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person that Daniel saw was not a normal man, but had a human figure like a man. “I also saw that night someone coming who resembled a son of man, that is, he had a human figure” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: I saw one coming & like a son of man

contextId.occurrenceNote: His body gleamed with blue or yellow light as if it were made of topaz. Alternate translation: “his body gleamed like topaz” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: His body was like topaz

contextId.occurrenceNote: His face shone brightly as a bolt of lightning shines. Alternate translation: “his face shone with light as bright as the flash of lightning” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: his face was like lightning

contextId.occurrenceNote: His eyes were bright with light as if they were flaming torches. Alternate translation: “his eyes were so bright that it seemed they had torches burning inside them” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: His eyes were like flaming torches

contextId.occurrenceNote: His arms and feet were as shiny as if they were made of polished bronze. Alternate translation: “his arms and feet shone like polished bronze that reflects the light around it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: his arms and his feet were like polished bronze
