contextId.occurrenceNote: His voice was so loud that it was as if a crowd of people were all talking loudly. Alternate translation: “his voice was as loud as a huge crowd all calling out together” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: The sound of his words was like the sound of a great crowd

contextId.occurrenceNote: The way the large army covers the land will be like a flood of water. Alternate translation: “will be so great in number that they will cover all the land” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: will flood everything

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to God’s people who will share their wisdom with those around them. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: Those who are wise will shine like the brightness of the sky above

contextId.occurrenceNote: These people are compared to the stars that shine. Alternate translation: “those who turn … will shine brightly like the stars forever and ever” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: those who turn & are like the stars forever and ever

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Nebuchadnezzar and his soldiers, not only to Nebuchadnezzar. Alternate translation: “Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylonia and his soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylonia

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Jehoiakim and his soldiers, not only to Jehoiakim. Alternate translation: “the army of Jehoiakim king of Judah” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Jehoiakim king of Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Nebuchadnezzar and his soldiers, not only to Nebuchadnezzar. Alternate translation: “gave Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylonia and his soldiers” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: gave Nebuchadnezzar

contextId.occurrenceNote: Although Nebuchadnezzar did not do these things alone, it may easier for the reader to retain the singular pronouns. Alternate translation: “They brought … they placed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: He brought & he placed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mind” refers to Daniel himself. Alternate translation: “Daniel decided to himself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: Daniel intended in his mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “mind” refers to the king himself. Alternate translation: “I am anxious” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my mind is anxious

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is using the word “you” referring to the person’s mind. Alternate translation: “know the thoughts deep inside your mind” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: know the thoughts deep within you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” refers to the king himself. Alternate translation: “the king was arrogant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: his heart was arrogant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “spirit” refers to the king himself. His stubbornness is spoken of as if he were hardened. Alternate translation: “the king became stubborn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: his spirit was hardened

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “heart” refers to Belshazzar himself. Alternate translation: “have not humbled yourself” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: have not humbled your heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “spirit” refers to Daniel. It means he had was unusually capable. Alternate translation: “he was and exceptional person” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: he had an extraordinary spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the horn was boasting, using its mouth to do so. Alternate translation: “the horn had a mouth and boasted about doing great things” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: a mouth that was boasting about great things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “my spirit” refers to Daniel himself. Alternate translation: “I was very sad inside” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: my spirit was grieved inside of me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here a man is being referred to by his voice. Alternate translation: “a man calling from the Ulai Canal” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: a man’s voice calling between the banks of the Ulai Canal

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “he” refers to her descendant, and here it also refers to his army. Alternate translation: “He and his army will attack the army of the king of the North” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: He will attack the army

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “king of the North” includes his army also. Alternate translation: “The army of the king of the North will come” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: The king of the North will come

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases stand for the kings and their armies. Alternate translation: “the king of the South and his army … The king of the North and his army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.quoteString: the king of the South & The king of the North

contextId.occurrenceNote: The wise men addressed the king in the third person as a sign of respect. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: Let the king tell us

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

This verse is also part of Daniel’s prayer. He stops addressing God in the third person and switches to the more personal second person. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In this chapter, Nebuchadnezzar tells what God did to him. In verses 1-18, Nebuchadnezzar describes in the first person his vision from God. Verses 19-33 switch to the third person to describe the punishment of Nebuchadnezzar. Verses 34-37 change back to first person as Nebuchadnezzar describes his response to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In verses 1-18, Nebuchadnezzar describes in the first person his vision from God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In verses 1-18, Nebuchadnezzar describes in the first person his vision from God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote:
# General Information:

In verses 1-18, Nebuchadnezzar describes in the first person his vision from God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.quoteString: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God gave his kingdom to his holy people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the holy people received the kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “and consume and destroy it in the end” or “and completely destroy his royal power in the end” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: to be consumed and destroyed at the end

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God will give the kingdom and the dominion … to the people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The kingdom and the dominion & will be given to the people

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “something broke off the large horn” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the large horn was broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: The horn threw some of that army and some of the stars down to the earth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Some of that army & thrown down to the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “it defiled his sanctuary” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the place of his sanctuary was polluted

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the horn trampling on heaven’s army” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: heaven’s army being trampled on

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “who became king over the realm of the Babylonians” or “who conquered the Babylonians” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: who had been made king over the realm of the Babylonians

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “that Moses wrote about in the law” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: that are written in the law of Moses

contextId.occurrenceNote: “nothing has been done.” If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “nothing has happened” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: there has not been done anything

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “what you have done to Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: what has been done to Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “As Moses wrote in the law” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: As it is written in the law of Moses

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God gave the order” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the order was given

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “People will rebuild Jerusalem” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Jerusalem will be rebuilt

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “people will destroy the anointed one and he will have nothing” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the anointed one will be destroyed and will have nothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God has decreed ruin for the city and sanctuary” or “God has declared that the enemy army will destroy everything” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Desolations have been decreed

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “God has decreed that he will pour out a full end and destruction” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.quoteString: A full end and destruction are decreed to be poured out

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can also be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “God revealed a message to Daniel” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: a message was revealed to Daniel

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. “No one was with me, and I saw” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: So I was left alone and saw

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. “my bright appearance turned into looking ruined” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: my bright appearance was turned into a ruined look

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “Daniel, you whom God greatly treasures” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Daniel, man greatly treasured

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “God heard your words” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: your words were heard

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “you whom God greatly treasures” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: man greatly treasured

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “I became strong” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: I was strengthened

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “what the Book of Truth says” or “what someone wrote in the Book of Truth” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: what is written in the Book of Truth

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “his kingdom will break apart and divide” or “his kingdom will break apart into pieces” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: his kingdom will be broken and divided

contextId.occurrenceNote: The kingdom is spoken of as if it were a plant that someone destroyed by uprooting it. This idea can be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “another power will uproot and destroy his kingdom and others who are not his descendants will rule over it” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: his kingdom will be uprooted for others besides his descendants

contextId.occurrenceNote: This appears to refer to a plot to kill her and those who made the alliance. This phrase may be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “They will abandon her” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: She will be abandoned

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “hand” represents the control of the king of the South. Alternate translation: “the king will surrender the army to the king of the South” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.quoteString: the army will be given into his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may be expressed in active form. Alternate translation: “The king of the South will capture the army of the North” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: The army will be carried off

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “a great army that has much equipment” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: a great army supplied with much equipment

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people will refuse to acknowledge him as king because he is not a descendant of kings. Alternate translation: “a person whom the people will despise and will not honor as king” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: a despised person to whom the people will not have given the honor of royal power

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being swept away represents being destroyed. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “His army will completely destroy a great army as a flood destroys everything in its path” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: An army will be swept away like a flood from before him

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “He will destroy that army and the leader of the covenant” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: Both that army and the leader of the covenant will be destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: “When other rulers make a peace treaty with him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: From the time an alliance is made with him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This tells why their meetings will not be successful. Alternate translation: “The result of their actions will only come at the time that God has fixed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: For the end will come at the time that has been fixed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may be put into active form. Alternate translation: “others will give them a little help” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: they will be helped with a little help

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be put into active form. Alternate translation: “the land of Egypt will not escape” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the land of Egypt will not be rescued

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. You can also make it clear that God will save the people. Alternate translation: “God will save your people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: your people will be saved

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. You can also make it clear that God writes names in the book. Alternate translation: “whose name God has written in the book” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.quoteString: whose name is found written in the book

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “the man who was wearing linen clothes” or “the angel who was wearing linen clothes” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: the man clothed in linen

contextId.occurrenceNote: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: “all these things will have happened” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.quoteString: all these things will be completed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh does the purifying. These three terms mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: “Yahweh will purify, cleanse, and refine many people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quoteString: Many will be purified, cleansed, and refined

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word “we” refers to the men that the king is speaking to and does not include the king. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
contextId.quoteString: we will reveal

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “us” includes Daniel and the Israelites, but it does not include God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
contextId.quoteString: To us today

contextId.occurrenceNote: Daniel and Israel sinned and did wicked things, but “we” does not include God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
contextId.quoteString: we sinned; we have done wicked things

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “our” refers to Daniel and Israel, but not to God. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])
contextId.quoteString: our sins & our ancestors

contextId.occurrenceNote: This nominal adjective refers to people who are oppressed. Alternate translation: “people who are oppressed” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])
contextId.quoteString: the oppressed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here “we” refers only to Daniel. He may have used to plural form in humility to avoid taking credit for knowing the meaning of the dream that God had revealed to him. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Now we will tell the king

contextId.occurrenceNote: Since the tree represents Nebuchadnezzar, the masculine pronouns “his” and “him” in verse 16 refer to the same tree as the neuter pronoun “it” in verse 15. Alternate translation: “The man’s mind will change from a man’s mind to an animal’s mind for a period of seven years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-pronouns]])
contextId.quoteString: Let his mind be changed & seven years pass by

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “your” here refers to Daniel. The people are the Israelites and the holy city is Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: your people and your holy city

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word “your” is plural. It refers to Daniel and the rest of the people of Israel. Alternate translation: “Michael, the prince of your people” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.quoteString: Michael your prince

contextId.occurrenceNote: “12 months” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: “for 1,000” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: for a thousand

contextId.occurrenceNote: “when he was about 62 years old” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: when he was about sixty-two years old

contextId.occurrenceNote: “one hundred and twenty provincial governors” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: “for 30 days” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: for thirty days

contextId.occurrenceNote: “Two thousand three hundred evenings and mornings.” Here “evenings and mornings” is a merism that refers to everything in between, which means full days. Alternate translation: “2,300 sunsets and sunrises” or “2,300 days” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.quoteString: 2,300 evenings and mornings

contextId.occurrenceNote: “from the time Jerusalem was destroyed, it would remain in ruins for 70 years” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: there would be seventy years until Jerusalem’s abandonment would end

contextId.occurrenceNote: “many thousands” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: tens of thousands

contextId.occurrenceNote: “one thousand two and hundred ninety days” or “twelve hundred and ninety days.” Here “days” refers to a period of time. Most commonly rendered as days, but can also imply years. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: 1,290 days

contextId.occurrenceNote: “one thousand three hundred and thirty-five days” or “thirteen hundred and thirty-five days.” Here “days” is referring to a period of time most commonly rendered as days. However, it can also imply years. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-numbers]])
contextId.quoteString: the 1,335 days

contextId.occurrenceNote: “In year two” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: In the second year

contextId.occurrenceNote: “kingdom number three” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: a third kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: “There will be a kingdom number four” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: There will be a fourth kingdom

contextId.occurrenceNote: The gods were believed to shine brightly with light. Alternate translation: “Man four is shining brightly with light as a son of the gods would shine” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]] and [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.quoteString: The brilliance of the fourth is like a son of the gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the number three ruler” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the third highest ruler

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the number three ruler” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the third highest ruler

contextId.occurrenceNote: “the number three ruler” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the third highest ruler

contextId.occurrenceNote: “In year three” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: In the third year

contextId.occurrenceNote: “year 3 of the rule of Cyrus the king of Persia” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: the third year of Cyrus king of Persia

contextId.occurrenceNote: “after them a fourth king will come into power who will have more money than the three before him” (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-ordinal]])
contextId.quoteString: a fourth will be far richer than all the others

contextId.occurrenceNote: These are the Aramaic words that were written on the wall. Spell these words with the sounds that fit your language. (See: [[rc://*/ta/man/translate/translate-transliterate]])
contextId.quoteString: Mene, Mene, Tekel, and Pharsin
